Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 07:44PM NJMarilyn wrote: Laureen, I had a mastectomy with no reconstruction on 2/15/11.  I first saw the inciison when the bandaging was changed in the hospital before going home.  The doctor was talking and was just doing his job when I looked at the incision.  He made it seem like nothing and maybe that got passed on to me but I really didn't react either way.  I was worried about that too.  I did look at women who had mastectomies online so I felt prepared.  I am just happy that all went well and I am cancer free.  All the best to you.....
Posts.Title: how to mentally prepare for a mx? --- ---

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 11:28AM NJMarilyn wrote: I use Just For You Two in East Hanover, NJ.  They are wonderful and I can't say enough good about them.  Their number is: 973-581-7070.  I am sure you will be pleased.  Also, Hackensack Hospital no longer carry prosthesis/bras in their store.
Posts.Title: fitters in NJ/NY/PA??? caaclark NJMarilyn

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 08:42PM NJMarilyn wrote: Hi Lyn: It is an adjustment.  Immediately after my  mastectomy, I used a very light weight bra - it may be called a sleeping bra.  I looked into a prosthesis before surgery because I wanted to know what I would be dealing with after surgery.  They had these "puffy things" that I was able to put in the bra.  I had my surgery last February and I too wore baggy flannel shirts last winter and they sure came in handy.  I forget I am wearing a prosthesis during the day.  It is very comfortable for me.  I think the key is to go to someone who is very experienced in fitting the prosthesis.  I am a D cup.  Marilyn

Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 03:43PM NJMarilyn wrote: I will be having a mastectomy on 2/15 with no reconstruction.  The tumor is only 4mm but since I also have lupus, radiation is contraindicated in someone with lupus, hence the mastectomy.  I don't know any more about my tumor but will find out a week after surgery.  I am widowed and live alone but a friend has agreed to stay with me the first week after surgery.  I don't do well with anesthesia so I've been dealing with getting through surgery and have not really dealt with the cancer diagnosis yet.  I have decided to rent a hospital bed so that I can be sure I can get in and out of bed on my own.  Thinking good thoughts for all of us!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 01:45PM NJMarilyn wrote: Maxine:  All the best to you on Friday as you undergo your surgery.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2011 04:30AM NJMarilyn wrote: Hi Ladies: Had the SN mapping on Monday.  I had only one injection and it felt like a novacaine injection.  Tuesday I had my mastectomy and I was home on Wednesday night.  I have one drain.  I will not be having reconstruction. The SLN was clear.  Everything went well but I was still nervous.  The waiting is the worst part.  Good luck to all the rest of you who are having their surgeries in February.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 09:38PM NJMarilyn wrote: Red:  I was also scheduled for a mastectomy in November but came down with sepsis and was in the hospital for a week - then home for over a month on antibiotics.  I went off antibiotics for a week and then got bronchitis.  This is the second time I've gone for PAT's!.  My surgery is now set for 2/15/11.  Good luck to you..
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 06:14PM NJMarilyn wrote: I am having surgery on Tuesday and I'm wondering how painful the drainage tubes are when they are inside you.  I'm assuming they are not pleasant by what everyone has said.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 12:08PM NJMarilyn wrote: Thank you Nancy.  I am home.  I had a mastectomy on Tuesday and was home on Wednesday night.  One drain was placed.  The SLN is clear.  I am doing well and don't have much pain.
Posts.Title: NJMarilyn! BioAdoptMom3 NJMarilyn

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 05:10PM NJMarilyn wrote: I have had that happen to me about three months after surgery - not BC.  Evidently it is quite common according to my doctor.  It grew back fine but looked a bit odd in the meantime.  Since I am having a mastectomy on Tuesday, I am wondering if this will happen again.  I noticed it mostly after taking a shower.
Posts.Title: 3-months post-surgery and... my hair is breaking. Anyone else? sunshinegal NJMarilyn

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2011 11:18AM NJMarilyn wrote: Gabby: I just had my mastectomy on 2/15/11 and I had the sentinel node mapping the day before.  I had the radio-isotope and not the dye.  They applied EMLA cream and I sat with that for about 30 minutes and then I had one injection.  For me, the injection was a brief sting and then no pain at all.  I was glad to go the day before and get it over with and then only had to deal with the surgery the next day, but everyone is different.  Good luck to you. NJMarilyn
